awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Quantum Random Walks in the Bose Hubbard Circuit
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
Random walks of particles serve as a model for many different phenomena.  These include noise, tunneling, topological protection, and the onset of strong correlations. Their applications include precision tests of short-range gravity, and precise measurements of fundamental constants. This work will study quantum coherent random walks of microwave photons using a quantum lattice circuit. It will extend the capabilities of the circuit quantum electrodynamics platform into the regime of quantum many body physics, through the development of correlated state-preparation and measurement tools. By exploring the interplay of tunneling, topology, and interactions in a setting with sufficient coherence to permit the emergence of substantial entanglement, we will have the opportunity to develop intuition and quantitative coarse-grained models of correlated electronic transport in materials. These studies will train students in the intellectual and experimental tools of quantum science and quantum information that will play an increasingly central role in the US and worldwide economies.
 
Technical Abstract
Initial work will explore quantum-coherent random walks of individual photons in a 1D Bose-Hubbard quantum circuit lattice developed by the principal investigators, and then extend this technique to entangled walks of multiple photons in higher dimensions. This work will not only advance the state-of-the-art for manipulation, control, and readout of large circuit QED platforms, but will provide essential insights into the role of quantum correlations in the dynamics of interacting particles, with direct implications for electrons in high mobility 2DEGs and correlated electron materials in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The team conducting this research consists of:

Meg Panetta, Gabrielle Roberts, Brendan Saxberg, Andrei Vrajitoarea, Dave Schuster, and Jon Simon.

YEAR 1 

Suppression of DC cross-talk between qubit flux lines: We are developing architectures to flux tune the transmon qubits in the Hubbard chain that minimize the extent to which the B-field injected into the SQUIDloop of one qubit perturbs the frequencies of other qubits. We believe that the primary mechanism for cross-talkis un-controlled ground-return of the DC current in the superconducting ground plane, and are in the processof exploring a variety of options to reduce this cross-talk, including separate ground-returns for each flux loop, air bridges, and bump bonding. 

 

Fig. 1 - Improving magnetic flux biasing designs. a) old squid loop and flux coupler design b) newer squid loop and flux coupler design.

Improved, Parallel Transmon Control/Readout:

 

Fig. 2 - Purcell filters for low-loss readout. a) Photograph of the 8 qubit/lattice-site chip, with Purcell filter on each readout resonator. The purcell-filter/readout-resonator combination is the pair of wavy CPW lines attached to each transmon. b) The pair of coupled CPW resonators hybridize to produce a double-resonance spectrum, with a faster rolloff outside of the double-resonance reflecting the suppression of purcell loss outside of the double-resonator ?passband?. c) Full spectrum of all 8 CPW/readout resonator pairs.

We have designed a new chip for fast independent readout. Fig. 2 above shows measurements of the chip with 7 of 8 of the double resonators functioning nominally and one requiring slight design adjustments for optimal operation. The ability to measure qubits simultaneously without affecting their coherence will be key to measuring correlations in quantum random walks.

FPGA-based frequency synthesis for agile control of large quantum systems: To rapidly manipulate large quantum systems, we hope to move to the recently released Xilinx Zynq RF-SOC boards, capable of generating multi-GSPS microwave signals at baseband on 8-16 channels. This technology is an order of magnitude less expensive than commercially available giga-sample DACs. We will develop appropriate firmware to control these Xilinx boards, thereby substantially democratizing the quantum computing/simulation space, and allowing for significant scaling of the control tasks for the most advanced research groups.

 

Fig. 3- Agile 8-channel quantum pulse controller a) ZCU111 Xilinx RF System on Chip board with 8 DAC channels at 6.5GS/s and 8 ADC channels at 4GS/s b) Output of a digitally programmed fast DDS that can be frequency hopped to control multiple transitions of an anharmonic oscillator c) Block diagram of a full pulse controller that we are collaborating with engineers at FNAL to design.

We are rapidly developing this new FPGA based control system. It is capable of playing static waveforms, which is already enough to do some experiments with it but we are hoping to further develop more dynamic capabilities so that it can respond within the time of an experiment to measurements that are made. (In YEAR 2 we updated this to programmability in a homebuilt, custom programming language).

YEAR 2 

In the second year of the program we succeeded in compensating for slow and fast flux cross-talk as well as temporal drifts in qubit T1s and frequencies, and have been to explore quantum coherence in random walking particles by adiabatically melting from localized individual particles away from site-to-site degeneracy to delocalized particles at degeneracy.

 

Starting with a single photon in the highest energy single lattice site, and bringing the sites into resonance, we observe, at resonance, a delocalized excitation corresponding to the lowest energy particle-in-a-box mode. If instead we start with a single photon in the second-highest energy lattice site, we observe that the photon melts into the second lowest energy particle in a box mode. Finally, we melt three strongly interacting particles from the three highest energy single particle states, into a degenerate lattice.

 

 

 

 

Note that because we have negative tunneling, we are beginning in high energy states rather than low energy states.

 

This strongly correlated, strongly interacting superfluid should have exotic correlations and dynamical response, which we intend to probe soon.

 

To validate that we are making a pure state in the manybody melt, we ramp forward to degeneracy and then back to the initial configuration, and measure the overlap with the initial state (with localized photons), which we can perform conveniently in the local number basis.

 

 

 

We observe high overlap for fast ramps (~1ns), because the system cannot follow (tunneling too slow); for intermediate ramps (~10ns), we observe reduced fidelity due to non-adiabaticity, and partial following, leading to substantial heating. Around 300ns ramp time, we again observe adiabatic following, and then above 1 microsecond we observe particle loss.
